results.title: Low deposit, easy terms
results.brief_description: Sue Ford was one of the first feminist photographers and filmmakers in Australia, initiating her practice during the early 1960s in Melbourne. An active member of many feminist film co-operatives, her works explore Australian identity and feminism, excavating the effects of Australia’s colonial past through playful, innovative and experimental films. In Low Deposit Easy Terms, Ford interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, but instead of open Outback roads, the viewer tours inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

In Low deposit, easy terms, Ford interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, but instead of open Outback roads, the viewer tours inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Victorian Women's Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Women’s Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

results.title: Straford video memories
results.creator_credit: John Straford, Frank Straford and Inala Video
results.brief_description:
Video memories of the Victorian west coast and bushfires in the north-east produced by the Straford family.
“Gone to blazes” contains footage broadcast by national and commercial TV channels during the course of the devastating bushfires that ravaged the Victorian north-east early in 2003.

results.title: Beneath our feet. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: Bob Scarfe and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: The Scenery of Victoria looks at the landforms throughout the state and relates the actual location to its geological significance. “Geological history of Victoria” Very similar to Part 1, but made for year 10 science with more emphasis on the period of history each geological type fits into. “Granite” looks at the formation and coding processes that produce granite with emphasis on the seven types of rocks that are currently associated with granite.

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Dale Baker, Open Channel Productions, La Trobe University, Preston Institute of Technology and Hodja Ed Res Co-op
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.

results.title: Billabong
results.brief_description: Set among the red gums, this film captures the mood of one day on the Murray River, Echuca, Victoria. Shows where thousands of birds come to breed each year.

results.title: Gum preparation, stone flaking etc; (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “People of the Australian Western Desert (A)”
Scenes typical of the daily life of nomadic First Nations people of the Pintubi tribe in desert conditions, filmed in the Clutterbuck Hills area, Western Australia. Gum preparation, stone flaking, Djagamara leave Badjar.

results.title: Seed cake making and general camp activity
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People of the Australian Western Desert (A)”
Scenes typical of the daily life of nomadic First Nations people of the Pintubi tribe in desert conditions, filmed in the Clutterbuck Hills area, Western Australia. The women of the family group gather grass seed. Back in camp, surrounded by their family they make seed cake.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Australian diary. No. 050
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: a self-taught sculptor makes First Nations people the subject of his work; a Child Welfare Centre is a boon in New Guinea; plastic bowls show they run true to form and a history of duelling through the ages is shown.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 005
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This cinemagazine features the following items: swimming instruction classes in New South Wales; problems with traffic in Melbourne; First Nations people show their skill with the stockwhip; Sulman architectural awards and strange animals at the Melbourne Zoo.
